Author: Bernz - Selling LABS#9130
Content: https://twitter.com/notsofast/status/1206562662341054464?s=19 I claimed that kmd solved the Oracle problem, I'd say what he is requesting is a valid argument.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how do you bribe all nodes in the network to accept an invalid timestamp?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
it uses a similar mechanism as how timestamps are accepted. if there is a timestamp that is out of range, all nodes would reject it. so if you can bribe nodes to accept a timestamp from next month as valid, then it seems you can bribe the DTO, but that sort of thing isnt possible the way the consensus is done.

you could maybe bribe the source of the datafeed at the api level, but technically what the DTO is reaching consensus on is the value provided by the specified api, so if that api is changing its value, the DTO is technically correct to track that change

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anyway, i am curious as to what attack vectors there are to getting nodes to accept a timestamp one month in the future. since all nodes will reject such a timestamp as being too far from the future, no amount of bribery would work. MITM doesnt make sense in this context. you can ddos nodes from the network, but the ones that remain are still following the consensus rule

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe we should have some sort of battle testing of DTO for people that are not convinced by code. of course, there could be implementation issues as with anything, but at the high level putting the oracle in the actual block consensus itself is a new way for oracles and it avoids the issues that plague aggregated oracles

Author: gcharang#6833
jl777c#5810
Content: the thing is that the pegs builds on top of a DTO, so what i said is valid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: other pegged coins need to have some non-DTO oracle and are subject to bribery, MITM, and other attacks that make aggregated oracles not very reliable for large amounts. it is possible to make a complex deposit/reputation system, but that only works until the amount at stake is bigger than the value of all the coins deposited

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the DTO avoids all that complexity

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
yes, I was talking about this screenshot which explained pegs
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EL0UrzCUUAAt4FF?format=jpg&name=large
right after that, bernz mentioned oracles and notsofast countered with that tweet about ddos and mtm

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am eager to hear how you can MITM the timestamp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: every node is independently getting the price data via the same api

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
I'am not saying anything about the DTO implementation.
 I just said notsofast saw an explanation for pegs and thought that was about DTO, so I pointed the blog post to share with him about DTO

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a good point that we should try to break it, but other than finding implementation bugs, i am not sure how one would go about corrupting the price

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
yes, the worst that can happen is a stalled chain
but the mechanism ensures that, if the chain is progressing properly, the data is correct

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if the prices are being messed up, stalling the chain is probably a decent way to mitigate damages. by having it notarized, there will be a notarized chain that can be followed
